awd_titl_txt: Molecular Mechanisms of CO2 Signal Transduction in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants have many small openings or pores (termed stomata) on the surface of their leaves, by means of which plants control the exchange of gases with the atmosphere. It is through the stomata that plants also lose water vapor; over 95% of plant water loss occurs by transpiration from stomatal pores. Stomatal pores are formed by a pair of guard cells that (by changing shape) control the size of the pore and thereby simultaneously control the rate of water loss from the leaf and the diffusion into the leaf of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere needed for photosynthesis and ultimately growth. There are large changes in the levels of carbon dioxide in the leaves of plants during the day, caused by photosynthesis and respiration. In the longer term, atmospheric carbon dioxide levels are increasing; presently they are 40% higher than before the industrial revolution and are predicted to double during this century. This project will identify and characterize the mechanisms by which plants sense the level of carbon dioxide and use this 1) to regulate the size of the stomatal apertures and 2) to control the number of stomatal pores that form during leaf development. The role of the stomatal pores in simultaneously controlling carbon dioxide exchange and the loss of water from the plant place them in a role central to the response of plants to the continuing increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide and changing patterns of temperature, drought and their associated stresses. However, relatively little is known about the cellular, molecular, genetic and biophysical signaling mechanisms that mediate carbon dioxide control of stomatal function. Identification of the molecular network that controls stomatal aperture and development and understanding physiological function will help predict the effects of rising atmospheric carbon dioxide levels on plants and can contribute to future engineering of crop plants to help avoid heat stress of leaves and enhance their efficiency of water use. In addition to training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, the project will provide opportunities for public outreach and research experiences for students from disadvantaged groups underrepresented in science and technology from the Preuss Charter School in San Diego. 

A network of signal transduction mechanisms sense and transduce changes in carbon dioxide concentrations to regulate both stomatal movements and stomatal development in plants, thereby optimizing carbon dioxide influx, water loss, heat avoidance and plant growth under stress. Achieving a mechanistic molecular biophysical understanding of how the carbon dioxide stimulus is transmitted into the stomatal conductance regulation network is the long-term goal of this research. Robust carbon dioxide signaling mutants have been identified and their mechanisms of action characterized. However, the predicted intracellular bicarbonate sensors remain unknown. Furthermore, recent advances in this project have shown a key role of carbonic anhydrases in the repression of stomatal development by elevated carbon dioxide levels, leading to a model for carbon dioxide input into the stomatal development machinery. This project will investigate new working hypotheses by identifying bicarbonate sensing and signaling mechanisms in guard cells that function in carbon dioxide-induced stomatal closing. Functional multi-component reconstitution of carbon dioxide/bicarbonate signaling using heterologous expression systems will be used to identify the bicarbonate-activated proteins that mediate the carbon dioxide/bicarbonate response. The project will address the function of photosynthesis in guard cells for carbon dioxide control of stomatal movements and the functions of guard/mesophyll cell starch metabolism in carbon dioxide control of stomatal movements. The functions of the newly identified CRSP protease and CRSP homologs identified in a systems level cell wall proteome analysis will be characterized, and a mathematical model and model-driven experiments will be used to identify new mechanisms that function in carbon dioxide regulation of stomatal development. The carbon dioxide regulation of stomatal conductance will also be investigated using a genomic scale new artificial microRNA library recently developed in the laboratory.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:  Stomatal pores are formed by guard cell pairs in the epidermis of leaves. Stomata regulate the diffusion of carbon dioxide (CO2) into leaves for photosynthetic carbon fixation and control transpirational water loss of plants. A network of signal transduction mechanisms sense and transduce [CO2] changes to regulate stomatal conductance for optimization of CO2 influx, water loss and plant growth under diverse conditions. Photosynthesis and respiration cause large daily CO2 concentration (Ci) changes in leaves. Moreover, atmospheric [CO2] is predicted to double during this century and this continuing [CO2] rise reduces stomatal conductance of plants. This will have profound effects on global gas exchange, plant water use efficiency of plants and leaf heat stress. However, relatively little was known about the cellular, molecular, genetic and biophysical signaling mechanisms that mediate CO2 control of stomatal conductance in plants.

Important advances were made in understanding CO2 signal transduction mechanisms in the regulation of stomatal conductance, funded by this NSF grant. This project investigated new working hypotheses and identified CO2/bicarbonate signaling and sensing mechanisms in guard cells that function in carbon dioxide-induced stomatal closing. Mathematical CO2/bicarbonate diffusion modeling and model-guided new experimental findings using carbonic anhydrases that are targeted to three different locations in guard cells showed two possible cellular sites in guard cells that transmit the CO2 response, including at the plasma membrane. Guard cell chloroplast targeting of a carbonic anhydrase could also complement the CO2/bicarbonate response.

As photosynthesis uses carbon dioxide/bicarbonate as a substrate, we investigated the function of guard cell photosynthesis in this response. Interestingly, we found that guard cell photosynthesis itself is not directly required for the rapid CO2 signaling response. Within this research we unexpectedly also found though that guard cell photosynthesis is critical for guard cell turgor production, most likely due to the need for energization of guard cells. We further found that stomatal opening triggered by red light utilizes the signal transduction pathway mediated by low CO2 via red light-driven whole leaf photosynthesis to a significant degree. These studies further pointed to alternate mechanisms than photosynthesis for high CO2/bicarbonate-mediated stomatal signal transduction. Functional multi-component reconstitution of carbon dioxide/bicarbonate signaling using heterologous expression systems was used to investigate candidate bicarbonate-regulated proteins that mediate the carbon dioxide/bicarbonate response.

Growth of plants at elevated CO2 concentrations down regulates stomatal development in leaves of many plant species. However, the genetic and functional mechanisms that mediate carbon dioxide input into the stomatal development machinery remained largely unknown. We investigated mechanisms of this high CO2–mediated reduction in stomatal density. We used a combination of a genetic and a proteomic systems level approach to identify candidate genes and proteins in this important CO2 response. We found that mutants in CA1 & CA4, in the secreted signaling pro-peptide EPF2, and a newly isolated secreted protease show impairment in CO2-induced down-regulation of stomatal development. Predictive reaction diffusion modeling of extracellular signals in this response points to additional important factors in CO2 control of stomatal development that are being analyzed. In summary, this research has provided frameworks, genes, mechanisms and working hypotheses for future elucidation of the signaling network by which the presently continuing increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration will affect plant gas exchange between plants and the environment.

 

Broader Impacts: Elucidation of the molecular mechanisms and signal transduction network by which CO2 modulates stomatal conductance is fundamental to understanding the regulation of gas exchange between plants and the atmosphere, will help predict effects of atmospheric CO2 elevation on plants and may also contribute to future engineering of leaf heat stress avoidance or enhanced water use efficiency in selected crop plants and plant carbon sinks in the face of the continuing [CO2] rise. The PI’s University has submitted patent applications on aspects of this research, one of which was approved.

The PI and Co-PI pursued outreach efforts through research training and preparation of under-represented high school students. The PI and Co-PI developed and pursued an outreach research internship program with the public Preuss Charter School for disadvantaged high school students in San Diego, which included mentoring, research training and preparation for higher education. This outreach program was rewarding for the PIs and successful for the students. All high School students mentored have been accepted and enrolled in 4 year universities with the goal of becoming the first members in their families to receive 4-year college degrees. The PI was further active within the San Diego Science Festival and visited San Diego public schools with diverse student bodies to discuss plant biology science and research and STEM education. In addition, both PIs trained and worked with postdoctoral and graduate scientists to prepare these trainees for their ensuing advanced independent careers in industry, academic research, science education and other productive careers.
